title: [Large-Scale] The Role of Instructional Designers in Distance Education: Scientific Instructional Design Strategies Using Chaos and Complex Systems Theory

context.prior_knowledge: Experience in elementary science education and remote teaching operations, understanding of basic science experiment design and variable control
context.additional_context: A science education course for in-service elementary teachers performing project-based assessments in smartphone-based restricted technological environments. Focuses on improving learners' scientific inquiry skills (observation, measurement, analysis, conclusion drawing).

learning_goals: Learners can apply core concepts of chaos and complex systems theory (sensitivity to initial conditions, self-organization, etc.) to the design of remote science education.
Learners can plan flexible instructional designs reflecting scientific inquiry processes in unpredictable learning environments.
Learners can develop three interaction strategies for small learner groups: sharing experimental observations, hypothesis verification discussions, and collaborative data analysis.
Learners can complete science inquiry projects utilizing smartphone-based assessment tools (sensor measurements, image analysis, etc.).

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
